Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Cardiovascular Regenerative Medicine

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either CaVaReM interventions, including stem cells and tissue engineering, or standard care as a control.

Participants.evidence: Participants were recruited based on eligibility criteria, including diagnosis of heart failure. The study was conducted in a clinical setting.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either CaVaReM interventions, including stem cells and tissue engineering, or standard care as a control.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted to evaluate the efficacy of cardiovascular regenerative medicine (CaVaReM) in repairing damaged heart tissue.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was improvement in cardiac function over 12 months, with a mean difference of 5.2% (95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured by sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 in the intervention group and 100 in the control group, recruited between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was improvement in cardiac function over 12 months, with a mean difference of 5.2% (95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group, with mild gastrointestinal side-effects.
